|January 28, 1982}} | children = 3 (including [[Lucy DeVito]]) }} '''Daniel Michael DeVito Jr.''' (born November 17, 1944) is an American actor and filmmaker. He gained prominence for his portrayal of the taxi dispatcher Louie De Palma in the television series ''[[Taxi (TV series)|Taxi]]'' (1978–1983), which won him a [[Golden Globe]] and an [[Emmy]]. A major film star, he is known for his roles in ''[[Tin Men]]'', ''[[Throw Momma from the Train]]'', ''[[One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (film)|One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest]]'', ''[[Ruthless People]]'', ''[[Man on the Moon (film)|Man on the Moon]]'', ''[[Terms of Endearment]]'', ''[[Romancing the Stone]]'', ''[[Twins (1988 film)|Twins]]'', ''[[Batman Returns]]'', ''[[Look Who's Talking Now]]'', ''[[Big Fish]]'', ''[[Other People's Money]]'', ''[[Get Shorty (film)|Get Shorty]]'', ''[[Be Cool]]'' and ''[[L.A. Confidential (film)|L.A. Confidential]]'', and for his voiceover in such films as ''[[Space Jam]]'', ''[[Hercules (1997 film)|Hercules]]'' and ''[[The Lorax (film)|The Lorax]]''. DeVito and Michael Shamberg founded Jersey Films. Soon afterwards, Stacey Sher became an equal partner. The production company is known for films such as ''[[Pulp Fiction]]'', ''[[Garden State (film)|Garden State]]'', and ''[[Freedom Writers]]''. DeVito also owned Jersey Television, which produced the [[Comedy Central]] series ''[[Reno 911!]]''. DeVito and wife [[Rhea Perlman]] starred together in his 1996 film ''[[Matilda (1996 film)|Matilda]]'', based on [[Roald Dahl]]'s children's novel. DeVito was also one of the producers nominated for an [[Academy Award for Best Picture]] for ''[[Erin Brockovich (film)|Erin Brockovich]]''. He stars as [[Frank Reynolds (It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia)|Frank Reynolds]] on the [[FX (TV channel)|FX]] and [[FXX]] sitcom ''[[It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia]]''. He directed, produced and appeared in graphic, short, horror films for his Internet venture ''The Blood Factory''.{{cite web |last1=Decker |first1=Sean |title=Exclusive: Danny DeVito Talks The Blood Factory and More - Dread Central |url=https://www.dreadcentral.com/news/23195/exclusive-danny-devito-talks-the-blood-factory-and-more/ |website=www.dreadcentral.com |date=25 March 2011}} DeVito's short stature is the result of [[multiple epiphyseal dysplasia|multiple epiphyseal dysplasia (Fairbank's disease)]], a rare genetic disorder that affects bone growth in those afflicted.{{cite web|last1=Jenkins|first1=Mark|title=For Richer And For Poorer, But What Of That Vanishing Middle?|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/09/26/224525155/for-richer-and-for-poorer-but-what-of-that-vanishing-middle|website=NPR|accessdate=5 October 2015|date=26 September 2013}}{{cite web|last1=Joseph|first1=Pat|title=Lights, Camera, Economics Robert Reich brings his message to the big screen.|url=http://alumni.berkeley.edu/california-magazine/fall-2013-film-issue/lights-camera-economics|website=Berkeley|accessdate=5 October 2015}} ==Early life== DeVito was born in [[Neptune Township, New Jersey]], the son of Daniel DeVito Sr., a small business owner, and Julia DeVito ({{nee}} Moccello).{{Cite web|title=Biography - Yahoo! Movies |url=https://movies.yahoo.com/person/danny-devito/biography.html |work=movies.yahoo.com |accessdate=2010-02-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120303083600/http://movies.yahoo.com/person/danny-devito/biography.html |archivedate=2012-03-03 |df= }}{{Cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/91/Danny-DeVito.html |title=Danny DeVito Biography (1944-) |work=filmreference.com |date= |accessdate=2010-02-10}} He grew up in a family of five, with his parents and two older sisters.{{cite web|title=Danny DeVito: 'It all worked out for me. Life is good'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2012/apr/15/danny-devito-interview-sunshine-boys|work=The Guardian|author=Barbara Ellen|date=14 April 2012}} He is of Italian descent; his family is originally from [[San Fele]], [[Basilicata]].{{cite web|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2010-06-29/travel/tl.italian.getaway.devito_1_sea-view-rooms-restaurant?_s=PM:TRAVEL |title=My favorite place: Danny DeVito |author=Dani Shapiro |date=29 June 2010 |work=CNN |accessdate=31 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101111000532/http://articles.cnn.com/2010-06-29/travel/tl.italian.getaway.devito_1_sea-view-rooms-restaurant?_s=PM%3ATRAVEL |archivedate=11 November 2010 |df= }} He was raised in [[Asbury Park, New Jersey]].Shaw, David.[http://www.cigaraficionado.com/Cigar/CA_Profiles/People_Profile/0,2540,8,00.html "DeVito! Although He Has a Penchant for Dark Comedies, Actor-Director Danny DeVito Is Serious About His Craft, His Family and His Cigars"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070404023422/http://www.cigaraficionado.com/Cigar/CA_Profiles/People_Profile/0,2540,8,00.html |date=2007-04-04 }}, ''[[Cigar Aficionado]]'' profile, accessed May 2, 2007. "Danny DeVito was born in 1944 in the shore town of Neptune, New Jersey—hence the name of his production company—and raised in neighboring Asbury Park, the youngest of five children (two of whom died before he was born)." DeVito was raised as a Catholic and attended [[Oratory Preparatory School]], a boarding school in [[Summit, New Jersey]], graduating in 1962. He went to the boarding school when he was 14 after he persuaded his father to send him there to keep him out of trouble. After leaving the boarding school, he trained at the [[American Academy of Dramatic Arts]], from which he graduated in 1966. In his early theater days, he performed with the Colonnades Theater Lab, at the [[Eugene O'Neill Theater Center]] in [[Waterford, Connecticut]], and, along with his future wife, [[Rhea Perlman]], appeared in plays produced by the [[Westbeth Playwrights Feminist Collective]]. ==Career== ===Film acting=== [[File:Danny DeVito by Gage Skidmore.jpg|thumb|right|upright|DeVito at the [[San Diego Comic-Con International]] in July 2010]] DeVito played Martini in the 1975 film ''[[One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (film)|One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest]]'', reprising his role from the 1971 [[One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (play)|off-Broadway play]] of the same title. He gained fame in 1978 playing Louie De Palma, the short but domineering dispatcher for the fictional Sunshine Cab Company, on the hit TV show ''[[Taxi (TV series)|Taxi]]''. After ''Taxi'' ended, DeVito began a successful film career, starting with roles in 1983's ''[[Terms of Endearment]]'', as the comic rogue in the romantic adventure ''[[Romancing the Stone]]'', starring [[Michael Douglas]] and [[Kathleen Turner]], and its 1985 sequel, ''[[The Jewel of the Nile]]''. In 1986, DeVito starred in ''[[Ruthless People]]'' with [[Bette Midler]] and [[Judge Reinhold]], and in 1987, he made his feature-directing debut with the [[dark comedy]] ''[[Throw Momma from the Train]]'', in which he starred with [[Billy Crystal]] and [[Anne Ramsey]]. Two years later, DeVito reunited with Douglas and Turner in ''[[War of the Roses (film)|The War of the Roses]]'', which he directed and in which he co-starred. DeVito's work during this time includes ''[[Other People's Money]]'' with [[Gregory Peck]], director [[Barry Levinson]]'s ''[[Tin Men]]'' as a competitive rival salesman to [[Richard Dreyfuss]]' character, two co-starring vehicles with [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] (the comedies ''[[Twins (1988 film)|Twins]]'' and ''[[Junior (1994 film)|Junior]]''), and playing [[Penguin (comics)|The Penguin]] as a deformed sociopath in director Tim Burton's ''[[Batman Returns]]'' (1992) as well in the 1996 film adaptation ''[[Matilda (1996 film)|Matilda]]'' in which he played the villainous car dealer and Matilda's father Harry Wormwood. Although generally a comic actor, DeVito expanded into dramatic roles with ''[[The Rainmaker (1997 film)|The Rainmaker]]'' (1997), ''[[Hoffa]]'' (1992), which he directed and in which he co-starred with [[Jack Nicholson]], ''[[Jack the Bear]]'' (1993), ''[[L.A. Confidential (film)|L.A. Confidential]]'', ''[[The Big Kahuna (film)|The Big Kahuna]]'', and ''[[Heist (film)|Heist]]'' ([[2001 in film|2001]]), as a [[gangster]] nemesis of Joe Moore ([[Gene Hackman]]). DeVito has an interest in documentaries: In 2006, he began a partnership with [[Morgan Freeman]]'s company [[ClickStar]], on which he hosts a documentary channel called Jersey Docs. He was also interviewed in the documentary ''[[Revenge of the Electric Car]]'', about his interest in and ownership of [[electric vehicle]]s. ===Theatre=== In April 2012, DeVito made his [[West End theatre|West End]] acting debut in a revival of the [[Neil Simon]] play ''[[The Sunshine Boys]]'' as Willie Clark - alongside [[Richard Griffiths]]. The play previewed at the [[Savoy Theatre]] in London from 27 April 2012, opened on 17 May and played a limited 12-week season until 28 July.{{cite web|title=The Sunshine Boys - Reviews|url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/west-end-theatre/reviews/05-2012/the-sunshine-boys_4231.html|publisher=What's On Stage|accessdate=25 April 2014|date=18 May 2012}} DeVito made his [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] debut in a [[Roundabout Theatre Company]] revival of the [[Arthur Miller]] play ''[[The Price (play)|The Price]]'' as Gregory Solomon, for which he was nominated for a [[Tony Award]]. The production began preview performances at the [[American Airlines Theatre]] on February 16, 2017 and opened on March 16 for a limited run through May 7. ===Producing=== DeVito has become a major film and television producer. Through Jersey Films, he has produced many films, including ''[[Pulp Fiction (film)|Pulp Fiction]]'', ''[[Get Shorty (film)|Get Shorty]]'', ''[[Erin Brockovich (film)|Erin Brockovich]]'' (for which he received an Academy Award nomination for Best Picture), ''[[Gattaca]]'', and ''[[Garden State (film)|Garden State]]''. In 1999, DeVito produced and co-starred in ''[[Man on the Moon (film)|Man on the Moon]]'', a film about the unusual life of his former ''Taxi'' co-star, [[Andy Kaufman]], who was played in the film by [[Jim Carrey]]. DeVito also produced the Comedy Central series ''[[Reno 911!]]'', as well as the film spin-off ''[[Reno 911!: Miami]]''.{{cn|date=June 2018}} ===Directing=== DeVito made his directorial debut in 1984 with ''[[The Ratings Game]]''. He then directed and also starred in ''[[Throw Momma from the Train]]'' (1987),{{cite web | first=Janet|last=Maslin|authorlink=Janet Maslin | title=Throw Momma from the Train| url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9B0DE5D81139F932A25751C1A961948260 | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=1987-12-01}} ''[[The War of the Roses (film)|The War of the Roses]]'' (1989), ''[[Hoffa]]'' (1992), ''[[Matilda (1996 film)|Matilda]]'' (1996), ''[[Death to Smoochy]]'' (2002) and ''[[Duplex (film)|Duplex]]'' (2003). ''[[The War of the Roses (film)|The War of the Roses]]'' was a commercial and critical success, as was the film adaptation of [[Roald Dahl]]'s ''[[Matilda (novel)|Matilda]]''. However, ''[[Death to Smoochy]]'' and ''[[Duplex (film)|Duplex]]'' both had mixed reviews.{{Cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/people/chart/?view=Director&id=dannydevito.htm |title=Danny DeVito Movie Box Office Results |publisher=Boxofficemojo.com |date=|accessdate=2010-02-10}} He also directed the film ''Queen B'' in 2005.{{cite web|last=Schneider|first=Michael|title=DeVito king of ‘Queen B’|url=https://variety.com/2005/scene/news/devito-king-of-queen-b-1117919178/|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|accessdate=25 April 2014|date=9 March 2005}} ===Television and voice-over work=== [[File:KaitlinOlsonDannyDeVitoRobMcElhenneyAug2011.jpg|thumb|upright|DeVito with ''[[It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia]]'' cast mates [[Kaitlin Olson]] and [[Rob McElhenney]] at the ceremony for DeVito on August 18, 2011]] In 1977, DeVito played the role of John 'John John the Apple' DeAppoliso in the ''[[Starsky and Hutch]]'' episode titled "The Collector".{{cite web|last=Raab|first=Scott|title=The Serene Beauty of the Five-Foot Fury of Asbury Park|url=http://www.esquire.com/features/danny-devito-interview-0214|publisher=[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]|date=31 January 2014}} In 1986, DeVito directed and starred in an episode of [[Steven Spielberg]]'s ''[[Amazing Stories (TV series)|Amazing Stories]]''. In the [[black comedy]] episode from season two, titled "The Wedding Ring", DeVito acquires an engagement ring for his wife (played by his real-life wife, actress [[Rhea Perlman]]). When the ring is slipped on his wife's finger, she becomes possessed by the ring's former owner, a murderous black widow. In 1986, DeVito voiced the Grundle King in ''[[My Little Pony: The Movie (1986 film)|My Little Pony: The Movie]]'' while his wife, Rhea Perlman, voiced Reeka the witch. In 1990, DeVito and Perlman played a couple (Vic & Paula) commenting on the state of the environment in ''[[The Earth Day Special]]''. In 1991 and 1992, DeVito voiced [[Herb Powell]] in the episodes "[[Brother, Can You Spare Two Dimes?]]" and "[[Oh Brother, Where Art Thou?]]" of ''[[The Simpsons]]''.{{cite web|title=Danny DeVito lends his voice to 'The Simpsons'|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2519&dat=19910211&id=Z65dAAAAIBAJ&sjid=rl0NAAAAIBAJ&pg=4448,1717906|publisher=Observer-Reporter|accessdate=25 April 2014|date=11 February 1991}}{{cite web|title="The Simpsons" guests stars over the years|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/pictures/the-simpsons-guests-stars-over-the-years/44/|publisher=[[CBS]]|accessdate=25 April 2014}} In 1996, he provided the voice of Mr. Swackhammer in ''[[Space Jam]]''. In 1997, he was the voice of Philoctetes in the film [[Hercules (1997 film)|''Hercules'']]. In 1999, DeVito hosted the last ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' episode before the year 2000. He earned a 2004 [[Emmy Award|Emmy]] nomination for Outstanding Guest Actor in a Comedy Series for an [[The One Where the Stripper Cries|episode]] of ''[[Friends (TV series)|Friends]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.emmys.com/celebrities/danny-devito|title=Danny DeVito|publisher=[[Emmy Award]]}} following four Emmy nominations (including a 1981 win) for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Comedy for ''Taxi''. In 2006, DeVito joined the cast of ''[[It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia]]'' as [[Frank Reynolds (It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia)|Frank Reynolds]]. In 2011, he received a star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]] for his work in television.{{cite news|title=Danny DeVito gets star on Hollywood Walk |url=http://ktar.com/category/tv-news-articles/20110819/Danny-DeVito-gets-star-on-Hollywood-Walk/ |agency=Associated Press |newspaper=KTAR.com |publisher=Bonneville International |date=August 18, 2011 |accessdate=August 19, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111001132000/http://ktar.com/category/tv-news-articles/20110819/Danny-DeVito-gets-star-on-Hollywood-Walk/ |archivedate=October 1, 2011 |df= }} In 2012, DeVito voiced [[the Lorax]] in ''[[The Lorax (film)|The Lorax]]''. In 2013, along with [[Rashida Jones]], he voiced Herb for the third time on "[[The Changing of the Guardian]]" episode of ''The Simpsons'' (aired on January 27, 2013. [[The Simpsons (season 24)#Episodes|season 24]], episode 11). He appeared in the ''[[Angry Birds Friends]]'' Champions for Earth tournament advertisement in September 2015. Following the Japanese release of the [[Nintendo 3DS]] game ''[[Detective Pikachu]]'', dedicated ''[[Pokémon]]'' fans started a petition requesting DeVito as the English voice actor for the titular character. The petition gained 40,000 signatures, but he declined to audition for the role, making a comment implying that he is unfamiliar with the popular franchise.{{Cite web|title = Pokémon Fans Petitioning to Make Danny DeVito the Voice of Pikachu (He’d Be Perfect)|url = https://www.yahoo.com/tech/pokemon-fans-are-petitioining-to-make-danny-174608577.html|publisher=[[Yahoo!]]|access-date = 2016-02-12}}{{cite web|title = Paley Center on Twitter: "Audience Q:Will Danny DeVito voice the Detective Pikachu videogame? Danny says "No" and asks what it is, "What the F is Pokemon?" #PaleyLive|url = https://twitter.com/paleycenter/status/716108571969126407?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw|publisher=[[Twitter]]|access-date = 2016-05-02}} ==Appearances in other media== DeVito played a fictional version of himself in the music video for [[One Direction]]'s song "[[Steal My Girl]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1960554/one-direction-steal-my-girl-video-features-danny-devito/|title=One Direction's 'Steal My Girl' Video Features Danny DeVito... What!?|work=MTV News|accessdate=7 May 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop-shop/6281535/one-direction-danny-devito-steal-my-girl-video-photos|title=One Direction's New 'Steal My Girl' Video Will Feature Danny DeVito|date=11 October 2014|work=Billboard.com|accessdate=19 October 2014}} He also appeared in the short film ''Curmudgeons''{{Cite web|url=http://www.curmudgeonsfilm.com/|title=Curmudgeons|last=|first=|date=|website=Curmudgeons|publisher=|access-date=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161013071615/http://www.curmudgeonsfilm.com/|archivedate=2016-10-13|df=}} which he has also produced and directed. ==Personal life== [[File:Rhea Perlman Danny DeVito 2006.jpg|thumb|DeVito with [[Rhea Perlman]]]] On January 17, 1971, DeVito met [[Rhea Perlman]] when she went to see a friend in the single performance of the play ''The Shrinking Bride'', which also featured DeVito.{{Cite book| authorlink=Frank Lovece|first=Frank | last=Lovece | first2= Jules | last2= with Franco | title=Hailing Taxi: The Official Book of the Show | year = 1988 | location = New York | publisher = [[Simon & Schuster]] / [[Prentice Hall Press]] | pages = 53, 286 | isbn = 978-0-13-372103-4}} They moved in together two weeks after meeting.Lovece, pp. 53, 80 The couple married on January 28, 1982.{{cite news | first= Carol | last= Wallace | date= December 12, 1983 | title= Chalk Up a Successful Marriage for TV's Tart-Tongued Twosome, Danny De Vito and Rhea Perlman | url= http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20086560,00.html | work= [[People (magazine)|People]] | accessdate= October 8, 2012 | deadurl= yes | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20121120221558/http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20086560,00.html | archivedate= November 20, 2012 | df= }} They have three children: [[Lucy DeVito|Lucy Chet DeVito]] (born March 11, 1983), Grace Fan DeVito (born March 1985), and Jacob Daniel DeVito (born October 1987).{{cite web |url=http://www.etonline.com/news/125687_Danny_DeVito_and_Rhea_Perlman_Separate/index.html |title=Danny DeVito and Rhea Perlman Separate |work=[[Entertainment Tonight]] |accessdate=October 8, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121010013810/http://www.etonline.com/news/125687_Danny_DeVito_and_Rhea_Perlman_Separate/index.html |archivedate=October 10, 2012 |df= }} Throughout their relationship, Perlman and DeVito have acted alongside each other several times, including in the television show ''[[Taxi (TV series)|Taxi]]'' and the feature film ''[[Matilda (1996 film)|Matilda]]'' (in which they played Matilda's parents). While DeVito and Perlman separated in October 2012 after 30 years of marriage and over 40 years together, the couple reconciled in March 2013.{{cite news | first= Elizabeth | last = Leonard | date= March 15, 2013 | title=Danny DeVito and Rhea Perlman Are Back Together | url = http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20682518,00.html| work=[[People (magazine)|People]] | accessdate=March 16, 2013}} The couple later separated for a second time in March 2017.{{cite news |first=Tilly |last=Pearce |date=March 27, 2017 |title= Danny DeVito and wife Rhea Perlman split for good three years after calling off divorce |url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/tvandshowbiz/3192728/danny-devito-and-wife-rhea-perlman-split-for-good-three-years-after-calling-off-divorce/ |work=[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]] |accessdate= April 5, 2017}} Although the two no longer lived together, they remained on amicable terms and Perlman had no intent of filing for divorce.{{cite web |title=Why Rhea Perlman won’t divorce Danny DeVito |url=https://nypost.com/2018/03/08/why-rhea-perlman-wont-divorce-danny-devito/ |website=New York Post |accessdate=9 July 2018 |date=8 March 2018}} In March 2018, [[Radar Online]] reported that DeVito and Perlman had reconciled once more and were planning on renewing their wedding vows.{{cite news |date=March 29, 2018 |title= Back In Action! Danny DeVito & Rhea Perlman Call Off Divorce & Renew Wedding Vows |url=https://radaronline.com/exclusives/2018/03/danny-devito-rhea-perlman-divorce-called-off-renew-wedding-vows/ |work=[[Radar Online]] |accessdate= March 29, 2018}} DeVito and Perlman resided in a 14,579 square foot (1,354 m²) [[Beverly Hills, California]] mansion they purchased in 1994, until selling the estate for [[United States dollar|US$]]24 million in April 2015. The couple also own a bungalow near [[Rodeo Drive]] in Beverly Hills, and a multi-residence compound on Broad Beach in [[Malibu, California|Malibu]].{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2015/dirt/real-estalker/danny-devito-rhea-perlman-sell-estate-1201474882/|title=Danny DeVito and Rhea Perlman Quietly List BevHills Estate|first=Mark|last=David|date=21 April 2015|work=Variety}}{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/realestate/hot-property/la-fi-hotprop-danny-devito-20150430-story.html|title=Danny DeVito, Rhea Perlman sell estate in Beverly Hills|first=Lauren|last=Beale|date=30 April 2015|publisher=|work=LA Times}} He and Perlman are members of the steering committee of the Friends of the [[Apollo Theatre (Oberlin, Ohio)|Apollo]], supporting a theater in [[Oberlin, Ohio]], as was filmmaker [[Jonathan Demme]].{{cite web |url=http://new.oberlin.edu/apollo/friends.dot |title=Friends of the Apollo |publisher=Oberlin College |accessdate=2009-07-06}} DeVito co-owned a restaurant called DeVito South Beach in [[Miami Beach, Florida]], which closed in 2011.{{cite web|title=DeVito South Beach|url=http://www.oceandrivemiamibeach.com/ocean-drive-dining-at-devito-south-beach/|publisher=Ocean Drive Miami Beach|accessdate=25 April 2014|date=20 October 2009}} In March 2016, DeVito endorsed [[socialism in the United States|democratic socialist]] [[Bernie Sanders]] for [[President of the United States|President]].{{cite web|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/in-the-know/in-the-know/272888-danny-devito-endorses-sanders|title=Danny DeVito endorses Sanders|first=Cheryl|last=Segal|date=14 March 2016|publisher=}}{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/billwhalen/2015/09/11/is-socialism-here-to-stay-or-is-sanders-just-another-dean/#792c7c1449d4|title=Is Socialism Here To Stay In 2016, Or Is Bernie Sanders Just Another Howard Dean?|work=[[Forbes (magazine)|Forbes]]|last=|first=|date=September 11, 2015|accessdate=July 11, 2017}} In July 2016, he endorsed [[Jeremy Corbyn]]'s 2016 campaign in the [[Labour Party (UK) leadership election, 2016|Labour Party leadership election]].{{cite news |last=Saul|first=Heather|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/danny-devito-jeremy-corbyn-and-bernie-sanders-are-the-only-shining-lights-we-have-right-now-a7164151.html|title=Danny Devito thinks Jeremy Corbyn and Bernie Sanders 'are the only shining lights we have now'|work= [[The Independent]]|date=30 July 2016|accessdate= }} In May 2017, before the [[United Kingdom general election, 2017|2017 UK general election]], DeVito said of Corbyn: "I like the idea of people telling the truth. I like them to get to the bottom of things, really." He endorsed Corbyn as [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]] saying he is "way better than [[David Cameron|[David] Cameron]]" and [[Tony Blair]], whom he called "that sketchy guy that hung out with [[George W. Bush|[George W.] Bush]]".{{cite news |last=Mortimer|first=Caroline|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/danny-devito-jeremy-corbyn-prime-minister-uk-election-2017-labour-grime4corbyn-940-a7744116.html|title=Danny DeVito endorses Jeremy Corbyn for Prime Minister using the hashtag #grime4Corbyn|work= [[The Independent]]|date=19 May 2017|accessdate=11 June 2017}} ==Filmography== {{Main|Danny DeVito filmography}} ==Awards and nominations== DeVito has amassed a formidable and versatile body of work as an actor, producer and director that spans the stage, television and film. As such he has received recognition from the [[Academy Awards|Academy awards]], [[Creative Arts Emmy Award|Creative Arts Emmy awards]], [[Golden Globe Award|Golden Globe awards]], [[Primetime Emmy Award|Primetime Emmy awards]], [[Producers Guild of America Award|Producers Guild awards]], [[Screen Actors Guild Award|Screen Actors Guild awards]], and [[Tony Award|Tony awards]].
